title: Quantile Regression Workflows (PyData Global 2024)
description:
This talk showcases and exemplifies the rapid specification and execution of Quantile Regression workflows. Various use cases are discussed, including fitting, outlier detection, conditional CDFs, and simulations, using different types of time series data.

Featured Python package, "Regressionizer": https://pypi.org/project/Regressionizer/
The "sidekick" Python package "OutlierIdentifiers": https://pypi.org/project/OutlierIdentifiers/

Dedicated presentation GitHub repository: https://github.com/antononcube/SimplifiedMachineLearningWorkflows-book/tree/master/Presentations/PyData-Global-2024

title: Simplified Machine Learning Workflows Overview (Raku-centric)
description:
In this presentation we overview the main Machine Learning (ML) workflows and their rapid specification through monadic packages. Additional facilitation is given by a Natural Language Processing (NLP) template engine and a Domain Specific Language (DSL) translator

We demonstrate that the ML workflows we consider are universal -- they have multi-language implementations in Python, R, WL, and others.

The overview covers Data wrangling, Classification, Regression, Latent Semantic Analysis, and Recommendations. Extensive explanations and examples are given in the book "Simplified Machine Learning Workflows."

This is the Raku-centric version of the talk I gave last week.

Please, buy me a coffee here: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/antonov70 .

title: Making of Rorschach mask 2D and 3D animations
description:
In this presentation we show a method to make animations of Rorschach images and project those animations over 3D surfaces. The work is inspired by the visual effects of Rorschach's mask in the 2009 movie "Watchmen".

See the Imgur gallery "Attempts to recreate Rorschach's mask" for examples (https://imgur.com/a/tzuzcWu).

The corresponding notebook can be found here: https://community.wolfram.com/groups/-/m/t/2518279

title: Random Mandalas Deconstruction in R, Python, and Mathematica (Greater Boston useR Meetup, Feb 2022)
description:
In this presentation we discuss the application of different dimension reduction algorithms over collections of random mandalas. We discuss and compare the derived image bases and show how those bases explain the underlying collection structure. The presented techniques and insights (1) are applicable to any collection of images, and (2) can be included in larger, more complicated machine learning workflows. The former is demonstrated with a handwritten digits recognition application; the latter with the generation of random Bethlehem stars. The (parallel) walk-through of the core demonstration is in all three programming languages: Mathematica, Python, and R.

Here is the dedicated GitHub repository: https://github.com/antononcube/SimplifiedMachineLearningWorkflows-book/tree/master/Presentations/Greater-Boston-useR-Group-Meetup-2022 .

title: FOSDEM2022 Multi language Data Wrangling and Acquisition Conversational Agents (in Raku)
description:
In this presentation we discuss the Conversational Agent (CA) designs for two closely related problem areas:
1. Data Transformation Workflows (DTWs)
2. Data Acquisition Workflows (DAWs)
The CA perspective is taken mostly for exposition and didactic purposes. The presentation is mostly demonstrations-driven. The demonstrated implementations are written in Raku.

title: Doing it like a Cro (Raku data wrangling Shortcuts demo)
description:
This video demonstrates the generation of Raku data wrangling code from natural language commands specifications. The demonstrated system consists of the following components: 1) macOS Shortcuts shorrcut, 2) web service implemented with Raku's Cro and run on a DigitalOcean server, 3) parser-interpreter of natural language DSLs into programming languages codes.

Here is the link to the RStudio's Shiny app: https://antononcube.shinyapps.io/DSL-evaluations .

Here is a link to the article this video was made to illustrate: https://github.com/antononcube/RakuForPrediction-book/blob/main/Articles/Introduction-to-Data-Wrangling-with-Raku.md .

title: NLP Template Engine, Part 1
description:
Demonstration of a system for code generation using semantic parsing of computational workflows specifications via Question Answering Systems (QAS). This first part has: problem formulation, big picture explanations, demo examples, interactive interface demo, algorithm design and walkthrough, bring your own templates demo. 
GitHub repository: https://github.com/antononcube/NLP-Template-Engine .
Presentation's slides: https://github.com/antononcube/NLP-Template-Engine/blob/main/Presentations/NLP-Template-Engine-slides-Part-1.md .

Please, consider buying me a coffee here: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/antonov70 .

title: Multi language Data Acquisition Conversational Agent (extended version)
description:

(This is the extended version of Wolfram Technology Conference 2021 presentation.)
Here is related GitHub repository: https://github.com/antononcube/Data-Acquisition-Engine-project .

title: Raku for Prediction presentation at The Raku Conference 2021
description:
In this presentation we discuss the architectural design and implementation of a software system for the specification, navigation, and utilization of computational workflows in the fields of data science, machine learning, and scientific computing. 

More specifically in the presentation we are going to: 

1. Introduce a simple, operational, and extendable system of natural Domain Specific Languages (DSLs) for the specification of computational workflows 

2. Outline a general strategy and a software architecture of a system that translates sequences of sentences of those natural DSLs into executable code for different programming languages (and packages in them) 

3. Discuss and demonstrate a Raku implementation of such software system and how to utilize it through Raku 

The system we describe in the presentation is multi-language from both natural language and programming language perspectives. We give a large number of illustrating examples of its functionalities, scope, and principles. We also demonstrate a "server solution" that uses the Cro library. At the end we discuss alternative approaches, system's current state, and future plans.

https://conf.raku.org/talk/157

title: OMLDSM Deep learning session 2
description: In this session we cover deep neural networks using R and the Keras package. Here is the link to the corresponding Meetup event: https://www.meetup.com/Orlando-MLDS/events/250086544/ .

title: Anomalies, Breaks, and Outlier Detection in Time Series (in R for Data Science User Group, Feb 2021)
description:
This is the recording of my presentation "Anomalies, Breaks, and Outlier Detection in Time Series" given at Champaign-Urbana Data Science User Group on 2021-02-5. 

See this link for the meetup details: https://www.meetup.com/CU-DSUG/events/jgrrbpyccdbhb/ ,
 
Here is a link to the dedicated GitHub repository: https://github.com/antononcube/SimplifiedMachineLearningWorkflows-book/tree/master/R/ChampaignUrbanaDataScienceUserGroup-Meetup-February-2021 .

-------

Please, consider buying me a coffee here: https://www.buymeacoffee.com/antonov70 .

title: Disk weight plate and kettlebell weight juggling combination
description: Disk weight plate and kettlebell weight juggling combination: the weight plate is 12 kg (25 lbs), the kettlebell weight is 16 kg (35 lbs.)

title: Two kettlebell weights front swap
description: Frontal swap (switching) of two kettlebell weights. Each weight is 16 kg (35 lbs). This is a simple exercise/technique upon which more complicated ones can be build.

title: Coronavirus propagation modeling, useR! Boston April 2020
description:
In this (tutorial) presentation we:

- Discuss the modeling and evolution of different scenarios of the coronavirus propagation and related disease
- Overview classic compartmental models in epidemiology
- Discuss the theory behind the System dynamics approach using simple examples
- Discus philosophical, scientific, and mathematical justifications
- Describe System dynamics' approaches of modeling the propagation of SARS-CoV-2 and the economic impact of COVID-19.

For more details see: https://github.com/antononcube/SystemModeling/tree/master/Presentations/UseR!-Meetup-Boston-2020 .

title: Investigating COVID-19 with R: data analysis and simulations
description:
n this presentation we discuss different aspects of COVID-19 modeling in R.

The presentation has significant technical elements, but most of the workflows are generalized and presented in ways that are easy to understand and transfer to other fields.

The presentation has three parts: data analysis, simulations, and framework design.

For more details see the GitHub page: https://github.com/antononcube/SystemModeling/tree/master/Presentations/R-Ladies-Miami-Meetup-May-2020 .

title: Phone dialing Conversational Agent WL prototype demo
description: Conversational agent for mobile phone dialing using Finite State Machine (FSM) design and corresponding grammar of commands.

title: Multi language Data Wrangling Translation - talk advertisement
description:
This presentation is to be given at "Data Science Study Group: South Florida Meetup" on 2020-10-7: https://www.meetup.com/Data-Science-Study-Group-South-Florida/events/273397708/ .

This presentation discusses how to facilitate the rapid specification of data wrangling programming code using natural language commands.

We want to do that because:

1. Often we have to apply the same data wrangling workflows within different programming languages and/or packages

2. It might be time consuming to express those workflows with the concrete language/package logic and syntax 

3. Natural language workflows are "universal"
  
We demonstrate data transformation code generation for different programming languages/packages. We focus on these three: R-base, R-tidyverse, Python-pandas.

In addition to code generation examples we also outline the utilized software strategy and architecture and the unit testing procedures.

title: Boston useR! QuantileRegression Workflows 2019-04-18
description: The goals of this workshop are to introduce the theoretical background of Quantile Regression (QR), to demonstrate QR's practical (and superior) abilities to deal with "real life" time series data and to teach how to rapidly create QR workflows using R.

title: How to simplify ML workflows specifications
description:
In this presentation we discuss a systematic approach of software development that gives us the ability to rapidly specify Machine Learning (ML) computations using both programming Domain Specific Languages (DSL's) and natural language commands.
We present in detail the selection of programming paradigms, languages, and packages.
